snippet: United States companies told the I.R.S. that they earned $129 billion in 2010 in Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands, but their real earnings are more complex.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column examines dubious rules that allowed United States companies to report earnings of $129 billion in 2010 in tax havens of Bermuda, Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands; says Congress should focus on eliminating loopholes that allow companies to claim profits at subsidiaries in low-tax countries in which they have few legitimate dealings.
